item.title: Captive Cetaceans - Mortality Investigation
item.description: Introduction So, here it is: my first ever contribution to the TidyTuesday project hosted on github! In this post, I am going to analyse a dataset on various cetacean species, originally analysed by Amber Thomas in an excellent Pudding article. Although this dataset is a less recent submission, I chose it because I was interested to learn a bit about the history of cetacean captivity and also their potential future in the context of climate risk.

item.title: Trump Tweets - Exploratory Analysis
item.description: Introduction The data that I have chosen to analyse in this document is a repository of Trump tweets which span roughly two years of data all the way up until Trump’s election as US president in November 2016. The original CSV file I have used in the following analysis can be found here on Kaggle. Credits My analysis of Trump’s tweets draws a substantial amount of insight from David Robinson’s recent screencast where he analysed a repository of medium articles - that specific screencast can be found here and I highly encourage anyone interested in text mining to watch it at their next available moment.

item.title: About
item.description: My name is Johnny Breen and I currently work as an actuarial consultant in London - for those unaware of what this job entails, I refer you to this gem. I started this blog after coming across David Robinson’s excellent presentation at the 2019 R Studio Conference, where he explained the - perhaps underestimated - value of making your work public. Indeed, the presentation made me realise that you lose out by not sharing your work with others: recognition and constructive criticism of your work are both crucial.
